headline: Upscaled: The cost of Columbia construction for struggling 12th Avenue businesses
footer: Produced by Jun Yi Zhang and Jason Kao. Maps by Charlotte Li. Additional development by Hong Sen Du.

page_0.value: Ramon Diaz, a longtime business owner in the Manhattanville neighborhood, views his restaurant as home. Throughout his time, Floridita has served generations of families and became a place where younger customers, who had originally eaten there as children, would later return with families of their own.

But that was before Floridita signed a lease with Columbia in 2010 to relocate from Broadway Avenue to 12th Avenue, as part of the University’s initial plans to build a state-of-the-art campus in the restaurant’s former location.
Continue reading Part 1, in which businesses relocated by the University discuss how they have adapted to their new locations.

page_1.value: This is the first part of a three-part series. Click here to read the introduction.

Roy Henley signed a lease to open Bierstrasse, a family-friendly beer garden, in Nov. 2015. He built the restaurant from scratch with his wife and his brother, a steel fabricator. His brother welded the frames for tables, and together, frame by frame, the brothers screwed on each wooden plank. For the centerpiece of the restaurant, they made a bar out of a large piece of wood that was thrown out from a brownstone being renovated on 146th Street.
It took six months for Henley and his family to finish the beer garden. They were immensely proud of their work.
Continue reading Part 2, in which businesses owners that arrived at 12th Avenue during construction describe the pain points in the corridor.

page_2.value: This is the second part of a three-part series. Click here to read the introduction.
Continue reading Part 3, in which key stakeholders describe how to save 12th Avenue and brace for the next stages of Columbia’s development.
